questions.text: Following consumption of a heavy meal with alcoholic binge, patient presents with severe upper abdominal and retrosternal pain. P/A shows epigastric tenderness. Serum lipase is 200, CXR shows left pleural effusion. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CECT thorax + abdomen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Boerhaave syndrome is a life-threatening condition that requires urgent imaging with CECT thorax and abdomen to diagnose esophageal perforation. Avoid invasive procedures like endoscopy as they can exacerbate the injury.
  • ➤ CECT thorax and abdomen

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement (s) about CA stomach: MC site in India is antrum H pylori is a class I carcinogen Lauren classification is applied to gross types of advanced gastric cancer Menetrier’s disease is premalignant
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lauren classification refers to microscopic subtypes of gastric cancer (intestinal and diffuse types), while Borrmann classification describes the gross appearance of advanced gastric tumors.
  • ➤ Lauren classification
  • ➤ Borrmann classification
  • ➤ H. pylori is a class I carcinogen and Menetrier’s disease is a premalignant condition.

questions.text: Fixing a strip of External oblique aponeurosis to re-inforce the inguinal canal is called:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Desarda’s repair

Explanation:

  • • Detailed Explanation of the Technique:
  • • In Desarda’s repair, a strip of the external oblique aponeurosis is sutured in place to strengthen the posterior wall of the inguinal canal. The aponeurotic strip acts as a natural, dynamic, and physiologically adaptable structure, offering support and reducing the risk of recurrence.
  • • In Desarda’s repair, a strip of the external oblique aponeurosis is sutured in place to strengthen the posterior wall of the inguinal canal. The aponeurotic strip acts as a natural, dynamic, and physiologically adaptable structure, offering support and reducing the risk of recurrence.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Bassini’s repair : This involves suturing the conjoint tendon to the inguinal ligament , not the external oblique aponeurosis. It was one of the first techniques developed for inguinal hernia repair and is now mostly of historical importance.
  • • Option A. Bassini’s repair
  • • conjoint tendon
  • • inguinal ligament
  • • Option B. Maloney’s repair : Maloney’s repair is outdated and not commonly used in current surgical practice. It does not involve reinforcement with the external oblique aponeurosis.
  • • Option B. Maloney’s repair
  • • Option C. Shouldice’s repair : This is a more complex repair that involves a double-layered suturing technique using native tissues, but it does not use the external oblique aponeurosis strip for reinforcement.
  • • Option C. Shouldice’s repair
  • • double-layered suturing technique

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Desarda’s repair uses a strip of the external oblique aponeurosis for reinforcing the inguinal canal and differentiates it from other classical hernia repair techniques like Bassini’s and Shouldice’s, which have different anatomical structures and methods.
  • ➤ Desarda’s repair

questions.text: 25/F undergoes exploration via McArthur’s incision for RIF pain. During surgery, normal appearing appendix is found. All of these steps will be performed except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Take biopsy of appendix

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When exploring for suspected appendicitis and finding a normal appendix, it is essential to rule out other causes like Meckel’s diverticulitis, ovarian torsion, and Crohn’s disease. A biopsy of the appendix is not indicated, but removal of the appendix may still be performed to prevent future complications.
  • ➤ DIFFICULTIES IN APPENDICECTOMY
  • ➤ DIFFICULTIES IN APPENDICECTOMY
  • ➤ Normal appendix- r/o Meckels, regional ilieitis, tubo-ovarian torsion Appendicular tumour- < 2 cm-
  • ➤ Normal appendix- r/o Meckels, regional ilieitis, tubo-ovarian torsion
  • ➤ Appendicular tumour- < 2 cm-
  • ➤ > 2 cm-
  • ➤ Crohns disease- If cecum healthy- appendectomy If cecum involved- avoid appendectomy
  • ➤ Crohns disease- If cecum healthy- appendectomy
  • ➤ If cecum involved- avoid appendectomy

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient has been diagnosed with proximal transverse colon carcinoma. The physician recommends an extended right colectomy as a treatment option. Which arteries should be resected during an extended right colectomy to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Ileocolic, right colic and right branch of middle colic

options.label: B
options.text: Ileocolic, right colic, trunk of middle colic, left colic

options.label: C
options.text: Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic

questions.correct_answer: C. Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the case of proximal transverse colon carcinoma , an extended right colectomy requires ligation of the ileocolic, right colic, and trunk of the middle colic arteries . This ensures removal of the tumor with an adequate margin and addresses the vascular supply to prevent cancer spread.
  • ➤ proximal transverse colon carcinoma
  • ➤ ileocolic, right colic, and trunk of the middle colic arteries
  • ➤ Types of radical colectomies and vessels ligated:
  • ➤ Types of radical colectomies and vessels ligated:
  • ➤ Right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and right branch of middle colic artery Extended right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and stem/origin of middle colic artery Left hemicolectomy: Left colic and sigmoid artery
  • ➤ Right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and right branch of middle colic artery
  • ➤ Extended right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and stem/origin of middle colic artery
  • ➤ Left hemicolectomy: Left colic and sigmoid artery

questions.text: An abdominal mass in a child with IHPS is best palpated by:

options.label: B
options.text: Palpate during feeding when child is quiet

questions.correct_answer: B. Palpate during feeding when child is quiet
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Palpate during feeding when child is quiet

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best method to palpate an abdominal mass in a child with IHPS is when the child is relaxed and quiet, often during feeding, allowing for easier identification of the pyloric "olive."

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with history of acute MI complains of acute, severe, and diffuse abdominal pain accompanied by multiple episodes of vomiting. Upon examination, his pulse rate is 110bpm with an irregular rhythm, while his blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg. The abdomen looks soft, not distended, and there are no bowel sounds. X ray abdomen shows diffusely dilated bowel loops. What is the next step?

options.label: A
options.text: NG tube and correction of serum potassium

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CECT abdomen angiogram

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with acute abdomen, severe abdominal pain, atrial fibrillation, and dilated bowel loops, acute mesenteric ischemia should be highly suspected. The best next step is a CECT abdomen angiogram to confirm the diagnosis and guide further management.
  • ➤ acute mesenteric ischemia
  • ➤ CECT abdomen angiogram

questions.text: 45/F presents with bleeding PR and pain in LIF since 2 days. Colonoscopy is performed as shown. Likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sigmoid diverticulosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The endoscopic features of sigmoid diverticulosis are small with mucosal outpouchings, and this condition often presents with bleeding per rectum and may be associated with left iliac fossa pain when inflamed (diverticulitis).
  • ➤ sigmoid diverticulosis

questions.text: A 73-year-old individual arrives with painless rectal bleeding. Which of the listed investigations are conducted for this patient? Colonoscopy CECT CEA Fecal calprotectin
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When an elderly patient presents with painless rectal bleeding, investigations such as colonoscopy, CECT, and CEA are crucial to rule out colorectal cancer and other serious conditions. Fecal calprotectin is not routinely used in this age group unless inflammatory bowel disease is suspected.
  • ➤ colonoscopy, CECT, and CEA
  • ➤ Fecal calprotectin

questions.text: John is a 45-year-old male who has been experiencing a bulge in his groin area that becomes more prominent when he coughs or strains. He has been diagnosed with an inguinal hernia and is scheduled for surgery. Before the procedure, the surgeon explains the condition and its potential complications. Which of the following statements about inguinal hernias are true? Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by gonadal vessels Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by Vas deferens Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by rectus abdominis. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by iliopsoas
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Triangle of doom boundaries: Medially by the vas deferens Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels) Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection
  • ➤ Triangle of doom boundaries:
  • ➤ Triangle of doom boundaries:
  • ➤ Medially by the vas deferens
  • ➤ Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • ➤ Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection
  • ➤ Myopectineal orifice of Frouchard boundaries:
  • ➤ Myopectineal orifice of Frouchard boundaries:
  • ➤ Medially by the lateral border of the rectus sheath. Above by the arched fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscle. Laterally by the iliopsoas muscle. Below by the pectin pubis and fascia covering it.
  • ➤ Medially by the lateral border of the rectus sheath.
  • ➤ Above by the arched fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscle.
  • ➤ Laterally by the iliopsoas muscle.
  • ➤ Below by the pectin pubis and fascia covering it.

questions.text: A 60-year-old smoker male presents with intense pruritis and waxing and waning jaundice. On abdominal exam, a globular mobile lump is felt in the right hypochondrium. He is a known diabetic with occasional alcohol consumer. How would you proceed with management in this case?

options.label: C
options.text: X ray abdomen → CECT abdomen → ERCP

questions.correct_answer: D. LFT → USG abdomen → CECT abdomen
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) LFT → USG abdomen → CECT abdomen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a case of suspected periampullary carcinoma with signs like a palpable gallbladder and waxing/waning jaundice in an elderly smoker, the sequence of LFT, USG abdomen, and CECT abdomen is appropriate for diagnosis and further management planning.
  • ➤ periampullary carcinoma
  • ➤ LFT, USG abdomen, and CECT abdomen

questions.text: All of these are indications for lap cholecystectomy: Single episode of biliary pancreatitis Type 1 choledochal cyst CBD stones with normal GB Acalculous cholecystitis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All are indications

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is indicated for a range of conditions, including biliary pancreatitis, Type 1 choledochal cyst, CBD stones with a normal gallbladder, and acalculous cholecystitis, to prevent future complications and manage underlying issues effectively.
  • ➤ Laparoscopic cholecystectomy

questions.text: 45/F underwent lap cholecystectomy. Histology of GB adenocarcinoma involving muscularis, without perineural invasion or margin involvement. What is the next step?

options.label: C
options.text: Extended cholecystectomy with Port site excision

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Extended cholecystectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For gallbladder adenocarcinoma involving the muscularis layer (T1b) without perineural invasion or margin involvement, the next appropriate step is an extended cholecystectomy to ensure complete resection and reduce the risk of recurrence.
  • ➤ muscularis layer (T1b)
  • ➤ extended cholecystectomy
  • ➤ CA GB
  • ➤ CA GB
  • ➤ T1a: Post lap chol-> Nothing T1b: Post lap choI-> Nothing if margin —ve, no perineural/vascular invasion). If +ve, extended cholecystectomy. NO PORT SITE EXCISION T2 / T3: Radical chole T4: Palliative
  • ➤ T1a: Post lap chol-> Nothing
  • ➤ T1b: Post lap choI-> Nothing if margin —ve, no perineural/vascular invasion). If +ve, extended cholecystectomy. NO PORT SITE EXCISION
  • ➤ T2 / T3: Radical chole
  • ➤ T4: Palliative

questions.text: The procedure shown in the image is commonly performed for:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Distal cholangiocarcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Whipple procedure is primarily indicated for malignancies involving the head of the pancreas, periampullary region, or distal bile duct, such as distal cholangiocarcinoma . It involves extensive resection and complex anastomoses to restore gastrointestinal continuity.
  • ➤ Whipple procedure
  • ➤ distal cholangiocarcinoma

questions.text: A 47-year-old female, known case of cholelithiasis, presented with acute upper abdominal pain. Examination revealed mild icterus and temperature of 101 F. Tenderness was felt in right hypochondrium. Blood work showed direct bilirubin of 5mg%, WBC 16,000 and alk phosphatase of 800. USG abdomen showed dilated CBD with intrahepatic biliary dilation. MRCP showed 6 mm filling defect in distal CBD. Which is the likely diagnosis and management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cholangitis, ERCP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with Charcot's triad and imaging findings consistent with a CBD stone, the diagnosis is acute cholangitis , and the best management is urgent ERCP to relieve the biliary obstruction.
  • ➤ Charcot's triad
  • ➤ acute cholangitis
  • ➤ urgent ERCP
  • ➤ If left untreated, cholangitis can progress to Reynold's pentad with hypotension and altered mental status due to sepsis. MRCP is supportive of CBD stones. Treatment for cholangitis includes broad-spectrum antibiotics, rehydration, and biliary drainage using endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).
  • ➤ If left untreated, cholangitis can progress to Reynold's pentad with hypotension and altered mental status due to sepsis.
  • ➤ MRCP is supportive of CBD stones.
  • ➤ Treatment for cholangitis includes broad-spectrum antibiotics, rehydration, and biliary drainage using endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).

questions.text: Identify the correct relations in pancreatic anatomy: Portal vein- Posterior to neck Splenic artery- Upper border Uncinate process- Anterior to SMV Sphincter of ODDI- complex of 4
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct anatomical relations of the pancreas, including the position of the portal vein relative to the neck of the pancreas, the course of the splenic artery, and the anatomical complexity of the Sphincter of Oddi. The uncinate process lies posterior to the SMV, not anterior, making statement 3 incorrect.
  • ➤ uncinate process
  • ➤ posterior
  • ➤ Uncinate process is posterior to SMA and SMV
  • ➤ Uncinate process is posterior to SMA and SMV

questions.text: MC cause of chronic pancreatitis worldwide?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alcohol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alcohol consumption is the leading cause of chronic pancreatitis worldwide, with prolonged alcohol use causing repeated inflammation and fibrotic changes in the pancreas.
  • ➤ Alcohol consumption
  • ➤ MC cause of acute pancreas: Biliary pancreatitis MC cause of chronic pancreas: Alcohol
  • ➤ MC cause of acute pancreas: Biliary pancreatitis
  • ➤ MC cause of acute pancreas: Biliary pancreatitis
  • ➤ MC cause of chronic pancreas: Alcohol
  • ➤ MC cause of chronic pancreas: Alcohol

questions.text: What of the below statements are true regarding Breast Conservation Surgery? Wide local excision Axillary node dissection Frozen section (biopsy) to be done during surgery Post-operative radiotherapy in all cases
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Breast Conservation Surgery includes wide local excision, possible axillary node dissection if indicated, the use of frozen section biopsy in some cases, and mandatory post-operative radiotherapy to reduce recurrence risk.
  • ➤ Breast Conservation Surgery
  • ➤ Breast Conservative Therapy (BCT) consists of:
  • ➤ Breast Conservative Therapy (BCT) consists of:
  • ➤ Wide local excision (>1cm) of tumor Sentinel lymph node biopsy (if clinically node negative) Post-operative radiotherapy – given in all cases of BCT If pre-operative axillary LN metastasis is present, no need for sentinel lymph node biopsy. Up front axillary lymphadenectomy is done along with wide local excision of tumor.
  • ➤ Wide local excision (>1cm) of tumor
  • ➤ Sentinel lymph node biopsy (if clinically node negative)
  • ➤ Post-operative radiotherapy – given in all cases of BCT
  • ➤ If pre-operative axillary LN metastasis is present, no need for sentinel lymph node biopsy. Up front axillary lymphadenectomy is done along with wide local excision of tumor.

questions.text: All of these are components of Van Nuy’s index except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Er/Pr status

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Van Nuys Prognostic Index for DCIS includes tumor size, age of the patient, tumor grade, and resection margin. ER/PR status is not included in this index.
  • ➤ Van Nuys Prognostic Index
  • ➤ ER/PR status
  • ➤ VAN NUY’S GRADING SYSTEM
  • ➤ VAN NUY’S GRADING SYSTEM

questions.text: 30/F presents with lethargy, weight gain and neck swelling. HP of swelling is shown. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic Lymphocytic Thyroiditis (Hashimoto’s thyroiditis) presents with lymphoid follicle formation in the thyroid gland and leads to hypothyroidism.
  • ➤ Chronic Lymphocytic Thyroiditis (Hashimoto’s thyroiditis)

questions.text: 65/M presents with neck swelling which moves up on deglutition. You perform a manoeuvre as shown in the image. Identify the incorrect statement about the condition:

options.label: A
options.text: Surgery is performed by neck incision

options.label: C
options.text: Blood supply comes from cervical vessels

options.label: D
options.text: The sign occurs due to narrowing of thoracic inlet

questions.correct_answer: B. All cases require surgical excision
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) All cases require surgical excision

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Retrosternal goiters may not require surgical intervention unless symptomatic or complicated. The Pemberton sign indicates thoracic inlet compression, and most retrosternal goiters can be managed surgically via a neck incision.
  • ➤ Retrosternal goiters
  • ➤ Pemberton sign

questions.text: All of the following are the components of MEN-3 except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Parathyroid hyperplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MEN-3 (MEN-2B) includes medullary thyroid cancer, pheochromocytoma, and mucosal neuromas but does not involve parathyroid hyperplasia. Parathyroid hyperplasia is a feature of MEN-1 and MEN-2A .
  • ➤ MEN-3 (MEN-2B)
  • ➤ medullary thyroid cancer, pheochromocytoma, and mucosal neuromas
  • ➤ not
  • ➤ MEN-1
  • ➤ MEN-2A

questions.text: The swelling shown in the image commonly arises due to abnormality in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sublingual salivary gland ducts

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ranula is a mucus extravasation cyst that arises from the sublingual salivary gland ducts and presents as a bluish, transilluminating swelling in the floor of the mouth.
  • ➤ Ranula
  • ➤ sublingual salivary gland ducts

questions.text: Which of these is not a usual contributor to the development of the ulcer shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Continuous pressure injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diabetic foot ulcers are trophic ulcers resulting from a combination of neuropathy (sensory, motor, and autonomic) and poor blood flow, rather than continuous pressure, which is the main cause of pressure sores.

questions.text: Identify the mismatch in C stage of CEAP classification of varicose veins:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) C4a: Lipodermasclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ C0: No visible or palpable signs of venous disease. C1: Telangiectasias or reticular veins. C2: Varicose veins. C3: Edema. C4: Skin changes without ulceration. This is further divided into: C4a: Pigmentation or eczema. C4b: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche. C4c: Corona phlebectatica C5: Skin changes with healed ulceration. C6: Skin changes with active ulceration.
  • ➤ C0: No visible or palpable signs of venous disease.
  • ➤ C1: Telangiectasias or reticular veins.
  • ➤ C2: Varicose veins.
  • ➤ C3: Edema.
  • ➤ C4: Skin changes without ulceration. This is further divided into: C4a: Pigmentation or eczema. C4b: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche. C4c: Corona phlebectatica
  • ➤ C4a: Pigmentation or eczema. C4b: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche. C4c: Corona phlebectatica
  • ➤ C4a: Pigmentation or eczema.
  • ➤ C4b: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.
  • ➤ C4c: Corona phlebectatica
  • ➤ C5: Skin changes with healed ulceration.
  • ➤ C6: Skin changes with active ulceration.

questions.text: Identify the mismatch nerve injury related to the surgery from below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C-3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Modified radical mastectomy : Injury risk to the intercostobrachial nerve. Thyroid surgery : Vulnerability of the external laryngeal nerve. Submandibular excision : Focus on the lingual, hypoglossal, and marginal mandibular nerves. Thymectomy : The vagus nerve is commonly at risk, highlighting the importance of anatomical awareness.
  • ➤ Modified radical mastectomy : Injury risk to the intercostobrachial nerve.
  • ➤ Modified radical mastectomy
  • ➤ Thyroid surgery : Vulnerability of the external laryngeal nerve.
  • ➤ Thyroid surgery
  • ➤ Submandibular excision : Focus on the lingual, hypoglossal, and marginal mandibular nerves.
  • ➤ Submandibular excision
  • ➤ Thymectomy : The vagus nerve is commonly at risk, highlighting the importance of anatomical awareness.
  • ➤ Thymectomy

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient is scheduled for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Which of the following is not an advantage of laparoscopic cholecystectomy compared to open?

options.label: A
options.text: Laparoscopic surgeries result in lesser post-operative pain.

options.label: B
options.text: Laparoscopic surgeries are cosmetically better as they result in smaller incisions.

options.label: C
options.text: Laparoscopic surgeries result in an earlier return to work

options.label: D
options.text: Laparoscopic surgeries require a longer learning curve for the surgeon

questions.correct_answer: D. Laparoscopic surgeries require a longer learning curve for the surgeon
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Laparoscopic surgeries require a longer learning curve for the surgeon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key advantages of laparoscopic surgery: reduced post-operative pain, better cosmetic outcomes, and faster recovery

questions.text: After MRM, the given device is placed in the wound bed to remove collections. What is the mechanism of this drain?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Closed suction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Closed suction drains (e.g., Romovac, JP drain) use active suction in a closed system to remove fluids. Open passive drains (e.g., corrugated drains) allow fluid drainage through gravity in an open environment. Closed passive drains (e.g., pigtailed drains) maintain a closed system but do not apply active suction.
  • ➤ Closed suction drains (e.g., Romovac, JP drain) use active suction in a closed system to remove fluids.
  • ➤ Closed suction drains
  • ➤ Open passive drains (e.g., corrugated drains) allow fluid drainage through gravity in an open environment.
  • ➤ Open passive drains
  • ➤ Closed passive drains (e.g., pigtailed drains) maintain a closed system but do not apply active suction.
  • ➤ Closed passive drains

questions.text: You are working as an ER physician, and a patient with a laceration has just been brought in. You decide to use the interrupted suturing technique to close the wound. What is the correct angle of needle placement for interrupted suturing technique?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 90 degrees

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct angle for inserting the needle in skin suturing is 90 degrees , which ensures optimal tissue approximation and reduces the risk of wound dehiscence.
  • ➤ The correct angle for inserting the needle in skin suturing is 90 degrees , which ensures optimal tissue approximation and reduces the risk of wound dehiscence.
  • ➤ 90 degrees

questions.text: Which of the following is not a boundary of the triangle of safety for chest tube insertion in a patient with pneumothorax on chest X-ray?

options.label: A
options.text: Lateral edge of pectoralis major muscle

options.label: D
options.text: Lateral border of latissimus dorsi muscle

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mid-axillary line

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anteriorly : Lateral edge of the pectoralis major muscle. Posteriorly : Lateral border of the latissimus dorsi muscle. Inferiorly : 5th intercostal space. Understanding these anatomical landmarks is crucial for safe chest tube placement in cases of pneumothorax.
  • ➤ Anteriorly : Lateral edge of the pectoralis major muscle.
  • ➤ Anteriorly
  • ➤ Posteriorly : Lateral border of the latissimus dorsi muscle.
  • ➤ Posteriorly
  • ➤ Inferiorly : 5th intercostal space. Understanding these anatomical landmarks is crucial for safe chest tube placement in cases of pneumothorax.
  • ➤ Inferiorly

questions.text: A 23-year-old boy got hit on his head while playing cricket despite wearing a helmet and fell unconscious. He was rushed to the hospital casualty. He woke up within 15 minutes in lucid state. Examination revealed stable blood pressure, a GCS score of 15, and a normal non-contrast CT scan. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Concussion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Concussion is a mild traumatic brain injury characterized by a transient alteration in consciousness, typically with no abnormalities on a CT scan. Always consider the mechanism of injury, the presence of a lucid interval, and imaging results when diagnosing head trauma.
  • ➤ Concussion

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of an 80-year-old lady who sustained a fall at home and presented with a headache and neurological symptoms after 3 weeks, with the given CT findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chronic SDH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic subdural hematomas are common in elderly patients after minor head trauma and can present weeks later with symptoms like headache and neurological deficits. The hematoma appears hypodense or isodense on a CT scan, distinguishing it from acute hematomas.

questions.text: 30/M after falling from motorcycle is brought is to emergency with head injury. Imaging done as shown. Identify the incorrect statement (s). Alternate periods of unconsciousness with normal spell Associated with cerebral contusion Associated with # temporal bone Ipsilateral hemiparesis may occur
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the characteristic clinical features of an epidural hematoma, such as the lucid interval, its association with temporal bone fractures, and the mechanism behind potential ipsilateral hemiparesis. Also, understand that cerebral contusions are generally associated with more severe brain injuries and not with EDH.

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding retroperitoneal hematoma:

options.label: A
options.text: Zone 3 hematomas should always be explored

options.label: B
options.text: Mattox maneuver involved medialization of splenic flexure to the right

options.label: C
options.text: Vessels injured in zone 1 should be embolized

questions.correct_answer: B. Mattox maneuver involved medialization of splenic flexure to the right
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mattox maneuver involved medialization of splenic flexure to the right

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Mattox maneuver involves the medialization of left-sided structures, like the descending colon and splenic flexure, to the right to expose the abdominal aorta and other central vascular structures. Management of retroperitoneal hematomas depends on the location: Zone 1 hematomas often require surgical exploration, while Zone 2 and Zone 3 hematomas are typically managed conservatively.

questions.text: A young boy with perineal injury comes to the emergency department. On examination, there was blood at the urethral meatus and the boy is unable to pass urine. Urinary bladder was not palpable. What is the next step in management?

options.label: D
options.text: Wait for bladder to fill and then perform SPC

questions.correct_answer: D. Wait for bladder to fill and then perform SPC
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Wait for bladder to fill and then perform SPC

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blood at the urethral meatus following trauma is a strong indicator of urethral injury. The correct management involves waiting for the bladder to fill to perform suprapubic catheterization rather than attempting to pass a Foley’s catheter or performing exploratory surgery. Recognizing the signs of urethral trauma and understanding the appropriate steps for safe urinary drainage are crucial in emergency medicine.

questions.text: A patient with stab injury was brought to the emergency. Vitas were stable. Image is given below. What is next best step of management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Further investigation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a stable patient with a stab wound, the next best step is to perform wound exploration and, if necessary, conduct imaging to rule out internal injuries. Exploratory laparotomy is reserved for cases where the patient is unstable or shows signs of severe internal injury.

questions.text: Which of these is not a component of revised trauma score?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pulse

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The components of the Revised Trauma Score: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), systolic blood pressure (SBP), and respiratory rate. Pulse or heart rate, although important, is not part of the RTS calculation.
  • ➤ RTS
  • ➤ RTS
  • ➤ Range: 0 to 12 Each parameter: 0 to 4 RTS of 0 to 2- dead RTS 3 to 10- immediate care
  • ➤ Range: 0 to 12
  • ➤ Each parameter: 0 to 4
  • ➤ RTS of 0 to 2- dead
  • ➤ RTS 3 to 10- immediate care

questions.text: Transplantation of kidney between mother and son is termed as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Allograft

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Autograft : Transplant within the same individual. Allograft : Transplant between genetically different members of the same species. Isograft : Transplant between genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins. Xenograft : Transplant between different species.
  • ➤ Autograft : Transplant within the same individual.
  • ➤ Autograft
  • ➤ Allograft : Transplant between genetically different members of the same species.
  • ➤ Allograft
  • ➤ Isograft : Transplant between genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins.
  • ➤ Isograft
  • ➤ Xenograft : Transplant between different species.
  • ➤ Xenograft
  • ➤ Identifying these terms is crucial for understanding organ transplantation and tissue compatibility.

questions.text: 50/M presents with painless profuse hematuria. Examination reveals right flank mass which is ballottable. CECT shows 5 cm renal tumor infiltrating Gerota’s fascia and infrathoracic IVC extension. What is the T stage?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) T4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of these are at increased of nephrolithiasis except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypercholesterolemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypercholesterolemia does not have a significant role in kidney stone formation and is the least likely to be associated with nephrolithiasis.
  • ➤ Hypercholesterolemia

questions.text: 45/F presents with painless hematuria. On cystoscopic evaluation, papillary mass of 0.5 cm is excised. HP reveals tumor restricted to lamina propria. What will be the management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Local chemotherapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Staging and treatment
  • ➤ Staging and treatment

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with symptoms of B.O.O. underwent TUR-P. The histology specimen revealed few foci of ca prostate, involving 10% of specimen. His serum PSA levels are normal and he has good performance status. Histology of tumor showed Gleason score of 7. What will be the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Radical prostatectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Radical prostatectomy is the preferred option in younger patients with intermediate-risk cancer, while hormonal therapy is reserved for advanced cases.
  • ➤ Radical prostatectomy

questions.text: 22/M presents with sudden onset pain during sexual intercourse. Examination is as shown. Injury is likely to have occurred at:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Corpus cavernosum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A penile fracture involves a tear in the corpus cavernosum and requires urgent surgical repair .
  • ➤ penile fracture
  • ➤ corpus cavernosum
  • ➤ surgical repair
  • ➤ PENIS FRACTURE: tear of corpora cavernosa
  • ➤ PENIS FRACTURE: tear of corpora cavernosa

questions.text: Identify the correct diagnosis on the basis of given image of newborn baby?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Exstrophy bladder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key features of bladder exstrophy , which presents as an exposed and everted bladder mucosa below the umbilicus, requiring surgical correction.
  • ➤ bladder exstrophy

questions.text: According to Wallace’s rule, genitalia represent what % of TBSA:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ According to Wallace’s Rule of Nines, the genitalia represent 1% of the total body surface area, which is crucial for assessing burn extent and planning treatment.
  • ➤ 1%
  • ➤ BURNS ASSESSMENT
  • ➤ BURNS ASSESSMENT
  • ➤ Wallace’s rule of 9 Size of patient’s hand with digits – 1 % Lund and Browder chart- also useful in children
  • ➤ Wallace’s rule of 9
  • ➤ Size of patient’s hand with digits – 1 %
  • ➤ Lund and Browder chart- also useful in children

questions.text: What is the appropriate management of the given endoscopic finding of DU bleed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dual endotherapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The preferred treatment for a bleeding duodenal ulcer seen on endoscopy is dual endotherapy , which combines injection therapy (e.g., adrenaline) with a thermal or mechanical technique (e.g., clipping). This approach is more effective at achieving hemostasis and reducing the risk of rebleeding.
  • ➤ dual endotherapy

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient underwent hysterectomy 2 years back, now presented with colicky abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. On examination, abdomen was tender with exaggerated bowel sounds. On investigations, multiple air fluid levels were seen in the abdomen. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Adhesive small bowel obstruction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adhesive small bowel obstruction is a common complication following abdominal surgeries such as hysterectomy. Key clinical features include colicky abdominal pain, bilious vomiting, exaggerated bowel sounds, and multiple air-fluid levels on imaging.
  • ➤ Adhesive small bowel obstruction

questions.text: Which of these is a true statement about use of compression stockings in varicose veins?

options.label: A
options.text: No benefit in preventing or progression of disease

options.label: B
options.text: Class I stockings are used in venous ulcer

options.label: C
options.text: Provide equal improvements in QoL and cost- effective compared to surgery

questions.correct_answer: A. No benefit in preventing or progression of disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) No benefit in preventing or progression of disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Compression stockings alleviate symptoms but do not prevent or slow the progression of varicose veins. They do not provide a permanent solution and are not as effective as surgical options for long-term outcomes.
  • ➤ Compression stockings

questions.text: Which of the following is not a treatment option for fistula in ano?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Internal sphincterotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Internal sphincterotomy is used for the treatment of anal fissures and not for fistula in ano. Treatment options for fistula in ano focus on eradicating the tract while preserving sphincter function.
  • ➤ Internal sphincterotomy
  • ➤ anal fissures

questions.text: A 1-day old baby is evaluated in the emergency department due to poor feeding, repeated bilious vomiting and not passing meconium since birth. Abdominal examination reveals a distended abdomen. Imaging shows the following picture. Identify the condition in this patient:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Meconium ileus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meconium ileus is a neonatal bowel obstruction, often linked to cystic fibrosis. It presents with bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and failure to pass meconium , with imaging findings such as a microcolon confirming the diagnosis.
  • ➤ Meconium ileus
  • ➤ bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and failure to pass meconium
  • ➤ microcolon
